target_assessment.notes: [The model fails the vulnerability_type and did not spot the issue in the ground_truth]

other_findings.model_claim: [The contract does not check the boolean return value of credential.transferFrom(). For ERC20 tokens that signal failure by returning false (instead of reverting), procureService() will continue executing even though no tokens were actually transferred. The function will still update critical state (serviceCost and owner), allowing a caller to obtain ownership and set an arbitrary new serviceCost without paying the token fee.]
other_findings.reasoning: [The vulnerability exixts in the contract's target function so the model's reasoning here is sound]

other_findings.model_claim: The procureService function is payable and requires msg.value >= serviceCost, accepting Ether into the contract. However, there is no function to withdraw the accumulated Ether, causing all received funds to be permanently locked in the contract, leading to loss of user funds.]
other_findings.reasoning: [The vulnerability exists in the contract's target function so the model's reasoning here is sound]
